trial_identification.studytitle: Normative anthropometric, body composition, bone health and energy expenditure in Singaporean adults
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A cross-sectional study to examine the anthropometric, body composition, bone health and energy expenditure in Singaporean adults

interventions.interventions: This will be a cross-sectional study. All participants will be asked to attend a testing session, where their anthropometric indices, body composition, bone health (optional), energy expenditure and blood profile (optional) will be collected at a single time point. The testing session will last a maximum of 2 hours and 20 minutes.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Composite primary outcome: Anthropometric indices including height (stadiometer), weight (Tanita BC-418), skinfolds (Holtain skinfold calipers) circumferences (Lufkin PM606 anthropometric tape), lengths (segmometer), and breadths (sliding caliper).

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Body composition such as fat mass, fat free mass, and total mass will be measured using BODPOD Body Composition Tracking System and dual energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA).
Bone health such as bone mineral density and bone mineral content will be measured using DEXA scan (optional).
Basal metabolic rate will be measured via indirect calorimetry using a ventilated hood system with the participant resting supine following a 10 hour overnight fast.

Fasting blood glucose concentration will be measured by finger-prick method using the Hemocue. A venous blood sample will be collected to measure insulin and lipid profile using the COBAS 4000 analysers (optional).

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Overtly healthy adults, defined as individuals who are not taking medications regularly and have not been diagnosed with any major disease.

trial_design.statisticalmethods: As this is an ongoing study aiming to provide a comprehensive reference data set, no power calculation can be provided. Participants' characteristics will be presented as arithmetic means and standard deviations. Categorical data will be presented as frequencies and percentages.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Singapore Institute for Clinical Sciences, A*STAR
sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Brenner Centre for Molecular Medicine 30 Medical Drive Singapore 117609

fundingsource.fundingname: Singapore Institute for Clinical Sciences, A*STAR

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Reference data can be used in clinical settings to monitor the growth of individuals and to identify those at risk for under or over-nutrition and assess their response to treatment. Reference data can come from either local or international sources. Local reference data should be compiled from measurements made on healthy, well nourished individuals. The group should be ethnically and genetically representative of the population to be investigated. Such data should be used when ethnic and genetic factors influence growth potential are predominant. Singapore is a multiethnic country, primarily comprised of people who are of Chinese, Malay and Indian ethnicity, and thus it is imperative that reference datasets represent the dominant races. The differences in anthropometric, body composition, bone health, and basal metabolic rate between Asians and Caucasians have been well documented. However, comparisons between the ethnic majorities in Singapore are scarce. With the use of a Singaporean reference dataset, ethnic specific tools to assess nutritional status could be developed for use in clinical practice. Therefore, the aim of this study is to create a "normative" / "reference" database on anthropometric indices, body composition, bone health, and basal metabolic rate in Singaporean adults of Chinese, Malay or Indian origin. The database will act as a reference point for clinicians and researchers in order to determine whether or not subject results are within normal ranges for their age and sex. It can also be used to establish ethnic specific indices of health risk.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Singapore National Healthcare Group Domain Specific Review Board
